What is your overall assessment of this course?

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Various general topics in nuclear and particle physics. A good introduction to the field.

some introductory nuclear and particle physics
most of the das and ferbel book

We spent the first half of the semester learning about nuclear physics at a basic level (if a nucleus with X protons and Y neutrons is stable or will decay, that sort of thing) and the second half of the semester learning like half a dozen rules about whether certain reactions of fundamental particles are allowed.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Baker is a very caring professor and clearly cares about his students. This class was taught at an accessible level and did not require too much work, but the topics covered were still very interesting. I think the lectures felt slightly disorganized at times, but other than that they were clear and interesting.
it's very chill and low stress ! especially for a physics course

The course as it stands is the natural successor in both course number and topics to 440-441, and yet it draws on quantum mechanics or advanced physics generally almost none at all. I figured we'd get maybe a minimal overview of Feynman diagrams beyond "this is what one looks like" or a touch of group theory as it relates to the standard model, and none of that was covered at a level anywhere near what the students in that class are prepared for. There were scattering problems which required classical mechanics, a bunch of formulas related to nuclear physics that a high schooler could've understood, and a bunch of reactions that either conserved baryon number or didn't. It was a disappointing lack of breadth or depth.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if they are interested in learning about particle and nuclear physics. The class is taught at a reasonable level and makes for a good physics elective.
Yes you learn quite a bit and it's a pretty chill class
